member.name: T:JetBrains.Common.Util.Concurrency.Testing.Concurrenzy
member.summary: Concurrency testing helper. Provides facilities to model threads interleaving based on checkpoints.
member.remarks:
The misspelling (Concurrenzy) is intentional to prevent collision with namespace name.
Use Concurrenzy.Checkpoint("name") in production code in "interesting" places and then use ConcurrencySimulator in test to model specific interleaving cases.
The Checkpoint() method is marked as [Conditional] and completely removed from production code by compiler.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Common.Util.DataPipes.Impl.DelayedActionsManager
member.summary: Stores actions that need to be performed after pipe activaton process is finished. Example of such actions is request for async data pipe update. If this action will be executed before activation is finished, async update may be started before all subscribers are registered. Therefore part of pipeline may not be updated. This manageer collects such requests and executes them right after last activation call frame is exited.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.Impl.PriorityTask`1
member.remarks:
State transitions:
Frozen -> Pending /* if task has cancelled in Frozen state, then it is just removed from queue; no state update happens */
Pending -> Executing, Finished
Executing -> Pausing, Waiting, Finished
Pausing -> Paused, Waiting, Executing, Finished
Waiting -> Paused, Finished
Paused -> Resuming, Finished
Resuming -> Executing, Paused, Finished
Finished

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.Impl.TaskInternalUtils.IsOperationCancelled(System.AggregateException)
member.summary: Checks whether AggregateException contain one and only one OperationCanceledException.
member.remarks:
NOTE. This method intentionally checks for single inner exception only.
Example.
If task A waits task B and B was cancelled then B.Wait() will throw AggregateException with inner OperationCancelledException. In turn, A.Exception will be AggregateException with inner AggregateException (from B) with inner OperationCancelledException.
Such case treated as A has FAILED not cancelled!

member.summary: Executes the specified action asynchronously via dispatcher with respect to lifetime.
member.remarks:
* If lifetime already terminated when InvokeAsync() called then action just ignored.
* If lifetime is terminated before action has been invoked then action removed from dispatcher's queue.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.ICanReportTaskProgress.Subscribe(JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.AsyncLifetime,JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.ITaskProgressListener)
member.summary: Subscribes listener for tasks progress.
member.remarks:
The events for each particular task are strictly ordered: OnTaskScheduled -> {OnTaskOperationChanged|OnTaskProgressChanged}* -> OnTaskFinished.
The events fired on task thread but NOT concurrently.
IMPORTANT! Long operation in handler will affect task performance.
If listener added when some tasks already scheduled then it is notified instantly for all scheduled tasks.
If scheduler's lifetime has terminated then TaskFinished might not be fired for currently scheduled tasks.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.IPriorityTaskGroup
member.summary: Group of tasks.
member.remarks:
Tasks in group are running concurrently with respect to allowed concurrency level.
The group has priority: foreground or background. Scheduler tries to run as many tasks from foreground group as possible. To achieve this it may pause tasks from other groups.
If foreground group contains less tasks than allowed concurrency level, tasks from background groups are executed. Which particular background tasks will be executed is implementation specific.

member.remarks: The only one group might have foreground priority, others automatically sends to background.

T:JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.TaskCallbackExtension
member.summary: Provides extension methods to specify task callbacks (success, cancel, failure, finish).
member.remarks:
The callback action invoked on the same thread that causes the task to transition into its final state. If the task is already finished when OnXxx() is called, the action will be invoked on the thread that calls OnXxx().
If callbacks are subscribed before task start then they will be invoked sequentially in order of subscription. Otherwise callbacks might be called in any order (possible concurrently - some from task thread, others from subscriber thread). If you need several callbacks in predictable order consider using .
Be aware, the (and any of Task.Wait) awaits task action only. This means callback action might be invoked after AwaitFinished returned.
If callback action throws an exception then it is logged via .
The lifetimed overloads of OnXxx() have the following behavior:
* if lifetime already terminated when OnXxx() called then callback just ignored;
* if lifetime is terminated before callback action has been invoked then action will never be invoked;
* if lifetime is being terminated when other thread already inside a callback action then Terminate() will wait while action has completed with timeout specified for async-lifetime;
If you need to bind something to lifetime inside callback action you should use .Instance, it will be terminated only after all tracked async activity have finished.
The OnXxxSynchronized() invoke callback action via captured Dispatcher.. Dispatcher is captured at the moment of OnXxxSynchronized() call, so it is must be called on UI thread only.
The lifetimed overloads of OnXxxSynchronized() act the same way as non-synchronized ones, i.e. callback action either never been invoked or awaited till completion.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.TaskWaitExtension.Join(System.Threading.Tasks.Task,System.TimeSpan,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Joins with another task with cancellation support.
member.remarks:
If reached then is thrown.
If is activated then is thrown.
If task FAILED or CANCELLED then produced by this task is re-thrown.
IMPORTANT! If task bound to the same (more precisely to the token of the same source) then Join() throws OperationCancelledException on cancellation request. But if awaited task bound to another token (either linked to or not) then Join() might throw either OperationCancelledException or AggregateException (see TaskWaitExtensionTest.Join_MightRethrowAggregateExceptionIfCancellationTokensDifferent test for example).

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.TaskWaitExtension.JoinOrThrowCancelled(System.Threading.Tasks.Task,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Joins with another task or throws OperationCanceledException if task has cancelled.
member.remarks:
In general case, when awaited task has cancelled it doesn't necessary mean that awaiting one should be cancelled too. So implementation of throws OperationCanceledException when and only when cancellation token is activated also.
For cases when propagation of OperationCanceledException is desired the JoinOrThrowOCE should be used.

member.summary: Starts operation progress with specified number of steps. Returns CURRENT instance of IExecutionController.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.IExecutionController.CreateSubOperation(System.Int32)
member.summary: Delegates some of progress steps to sub-operation executed synchronously. Returns NEW instance of IExecutionController. See for examples.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.IExecutionController.AttachSubOperation(System.Threading.Tasks.Task,System.Int32)
member.summary: Delegates some of progress steps to sub-operation executed in another task. Returns CURRENT instance of IExecutionController.
member.remarks:
The link between task is set up and attached starts report its progress to current task. The attached task might be obtained via of current execution controller or via of any other scheduler.
If current execution controller is disposed before attached has finished then 'Progress is out of range' assertion is possible.
Some schedulers might perform additional actions on AttachSubOperation, e.g. adds into current task's group to sync-up their priorities.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.IExecutionController.AdvanceProgress
member.summary: Advances progress on one step.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.IExecutionController.Yield
member.summary: Yields task. Execution might be cancelled or paused at this point.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.IExecutionController.Wait(JetBrains.Common.Util.Tasks.IWaitable,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Generic wait. Waits another task to finish, event to fire, and so on.
member.remarks:
If reached then is thrown.
The most implementations supports cancellation via CancellationToken, so even infinite wait can be aborted.
Also this method allows scheduler which executes current task correctly re-schedule work while current task is in waiting state.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Common.Util.IExecutionController.Fork``1(System.Func{JetBrains.Common.Util.IExecutionController,``0})
member.summary: Schedules new task via the same scheduler which executes current task.
member.remarks:
If current task is cancelled then forked one is cancelled too.
All forked tasks must be awaited before current controller instance is being disposed, otherwise 'Progress is out of range' assertion is possible. Anyway when current task action completes then all non-finished forks will be forcibly cancelled.
If you need independent sub-task you should schedule it directly via scheduler.

member.remarks: This property used along with by extension to provide effective parallel implementations of commonly used algorithms.
